title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [26 august 1868]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [26 August 1868]
text: Brooklyn 19 Aug 1868wensdayWednesday evening My dear Walti recievedreceived your letter yesterday as usual it was all right and am glad to hear you are feeling pretty well and every thing goes on pretty well with you you are so attached to washingtonWashington i dontdon't beleivebelieve you ever would be contented any where else i dontdon't wonder at it for i think you have more true friends there than any other place) i mean those not related to you of course) i suppose it makes you feel awkardawkward to go to mrMr. OconorsO'Connor's their not being friendly and you being friendly to both but when they move it will be different itsit's very disagreabledisagreeable to live in one house and not be on speaking terms i should think the oconorsO'Connor's was the last people to fall out with) well Walt here we are yet in the same old place but i doodo want to get out of it very much indeed there is so many children and not the best i ever see but a continual traveling up and down from morning till nightone good thing their dog is dead he filld the house with fleas so maybe wellwe'll get clear of them now) georgeGeorge says we must stay here till the 1 of octoberOctober and then he see what arrangements he can make with smith to take the house all himself and then we shall move there this winter i shall be glad enoughfenough maybeemaybe they will settle it up before i told georgeGeorge i wanted to move before you came home but walterWalter dear if it suits you better to come before that time you must come but i thought i should be so lonesome when i got away from this rabble that i should want you to come then and stay your full month) georgeGeorge has been to florenceFlorence to the foundry to get some big pipe they fell short and he dontdon't have much to doodo now he talks of going up on the island for a day or two) florenceFlorence is the foundry where jeffJeff has his pipe made when georgeGeorge got there JeffsJeff's inspector was out gunning georgeGeorge left word for him to come to the hotel it was some pipe that jeffJeff had they wanted for this main so when the young man came they told him mrMr. whitmanWhitman wanted to see he was quite alarmed he thought of course it was jeffJeff georgeGeorge thought he was very glad as he didentdidn't care for jeffJeff to find him out gunning) georgeGeorge has got a draft from jeffJeff for 510 dolldollars and got the money without any trouble) now walterWalter dear dontdon't wait till we move if it suits you i make a good deal of rectonengreckoning of your comingi feel pretty well at present Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [26 August 1868]
